contents.title: Tetra-Sail simulation
contents.abstract: Sailing has a range of positive impacts on mental and physi-cal health-related quality of life for individuals with tetraple-gia.  Multiple systems have been developed and studied tomake a sailing experience accessible and usable for this pop-ulation.  Unfortunately, access to many of these opportuni-ties are limited by extensive training requirements and costs.This work describes the iterative design process of creatingan adaptive sailing experience that requires minimal trainingand preparation for individuals with tetraplegia.  The Tetra-Sail is an accessible adaptive sailing experience that uses ashared-control approach to accept input from the main userof Tetra-Sail and an experienced adaptive instructor (controlpartner). This approach was used to create a usable experiencefor individuals with all types of physical abilities, includingparticipants with high level and complete spinal cord injuriescharacterized by loss of sensation and function below theirsite of injury, with minimal preliminary training. A study ofnine participants (five first time users of Tetra-Sail and fourusers who had participated in previous iterations) suggestedthat participants had a usable and enjoyable experience usingTetra-Sail. Participants expressed feelings of empowerment,which they attributed to the implementation of shared-controlwhich supported flexible adaptation to their abilities.

contents.title: Parallels, Tangents, and Loops: Reflections on the ‘Through’ Part of RtD
contents.abstract: While attention in Research Through Design (RtD) is often on the findings, in this pictorial, we choose to attend to the ‘through’ part of RtD in order to reveal the messy stories of how those insights were arrived at—stories that are often untold, truncated, or streamlined. We use a yearlong RtD project on human-data entanglements in the home as a case study to explore the contours of this process. We detail how our messy lines of inquiry crossed, dead ended, wove together, and looped. Grounded in illustrations of lines, we offer practical reflections on experiences we encountered while navigating these scribbly lines.

Talk.title: Parallels, Tangents, and Loops: Reflections on the 'Through' Part of RtD

contents.title: Communicating Sustainable Consumption and Production in 360° Video
contents.abstract:
Research at the intersection of technology and sustainability is increasing across disciplines. Virtual reality is one technology used to address social issues, though less work has explored how immersive environments might impact a viewer’s impression of complex environmental issues like sustainability. 
SCP in 360°: Sustainable Consumption and Production in 360 Degrees is a series of 360° videos aiming to make sustainable consumption and production understandable and engaging to a wider audience. In this paper, we describe the context and production of these videos, report on the visitor study conducted during the videos’ exhibition, and discuss the specifics of using 360° video for communicating sustainability and the broader implications for other 360° video projects and sustainability-focused interactive media. In contrast to research on empathy in virtual reality, our study suggests that 360° video supports participants in feeling compassion towards the situations viewed and understanding the context and complexity of sustainability solutions.

affiliations.dsl: School of Interactive Arts and Technology

contents.title: Exploring Potential Scenarios and Design Implications through A Camera-like Physical Odor Capture Prototype
contents.abstract:
Recently, researchers have become increasingly interested in finding new input methods for olfactory interfaces.
Physical odor capture is a potential solution to this issue and, in order to make it more accessible for users, we designed a portable and fast smell capture prototype based on headspace technology and inspired by point-and-shoot cameras.
We conducted a two-week diary study with 13 participants, in which they were allowed to freely use the prototype for odor capture activities. 
Through diary and interview feedback, we summarized factors such as the motivations of capturing, the collected odor types, and perceptual effects of odor replay. 
We found that the capture activities can positively affect user emotions, memory, or cognition. User preferences on device parameters were also gathered to guide further design iterations. Physical odor capture has many potential applications in daily-life and other implications resulting from the study have been proposed for further research.
